overview_of_class:
Prof. Joseph Ringel "Religion and Politics in the State of Israel" This course explores the historical development and socio-political impact of the relationship between religion and state in Israel both in terms of its domestic and foreign policies. As part of our exploration, we will delve into the extent to which the Israeli model represents broader trends in the Middle East specifically and in the world at large; the complex nature of the relationship between democracy and religion, and between religion and politics in a democracy; and the impact of religion on political violence and peace-making. This course will utilize academic literature from a variety of disciplines, including anthropology, political science, religion, and history, and will employ scholarship from interdisciplinary fields, including Jewish Studies, Islamic Studies, and Middle Eastern and North African studies.

Note that this course is a 300-level course, and as such, has a strong writing component, which fits the format and subject of the course better than quizzes or exams. The point is to think about and synthesize the material. As part of class participation, scheduled class debates, in which groups of students will need to respectfully present a case for a specific point of view, are planned.

overview_of_class: Fall 2017 Prof. Stevens "Political Theories of the Rule of Law" "The rule of law" is a phrase used to imply a range of expectations subjects or citizens hold of their governments and each other. This course will explore the origins of the concept, and read selected political and legal theorists reflecting on the relation between the form and content of law and the use of violence and civil penalties to maintain order, develop a national or religious identity, and instantiate individual rights in modernity. The course will focus on the jurisprudence of statutory interpretation, with special attention to U.S. laws that constrain government authority. We will read current laws, regulations, and court opinions as well as texts by Max Weber, Hans Kelsen, Walter Benjamin, Carl Schmitt, Franz Kafka, Jacques Derrida, and Michel Foucault.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be able to understand different theories of statutory analysis, as well as analyze U.S. government institutions and laws through characterizing the principles, assumptions, discourses, technologies, and historical contexts from which they emerged. Students also will be able to explain in writing and orally competing interpretations of laws, including their advantages and disadvantage.

overview_of_class:
Prof. TBA Global Development, Fall 2017
This course explores the economic and social changes that have constituted "development," and that have radically transformed human society. The course focuses on both the historical experience of Europe and the contemporary experience of countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. In the historical discussion, we explore the birth of the "nation state" as the basic organizing unit of the international system; the transition from agrarian to industrial economic systems; and the expansion of European colonialism across the globe. In our discussion of Africa, Asia, and Latin America, we consider the legacies of colonialism for development; the ways in which countries have attempted to promote economic development and industrialization; and issues of inequality and human welfare in an increasingly globally connected world.
